title: Henkel to cut 1,200 jobs in adhesives unit
text:
Henkel to cut 1,200 jobs in adhesives unit 5 October 2015 Print Email 
German consumer goods group Henkel has unveiled a plan to cut 1,200 jobs worldwide at its adhesives unit, due to a drop in demand. 
Henkel, the maker of Loctite glue and Persil detergent will cut 250 jobs in Europe and 100 in Germany by the end of the March next year. 
It will also remove 500 to 600 positions in the Asia-Pacific region, and 200 in the North American region, as reported by German weekly WirtschaftsWoche. "The group has made the decision as a result of the low sales growth reported in the year's second quarter." 
The group specialises in the production of adhesives, sealants and coatings for industrial customers, and has made the decision as a result of the low sales growth reported in the year's second quarter. 
The company said that its adhesive unit, including the Loctite and Pattes brands, was facing rising pricing pressure, according to Bloomberg. 
Henkel, which also makes Schwarzkopf shampoo and Fa deodorant, has its biggest adhesive markets in the US and China 
The company operates one of the largest adhesives factories in the world in Shanghai, and in order to extend its presence in other emerging markets, it is building another site in India. 
With around 500 employees, the Indian site is expected to start production in 2017. 
In 2013, Henkel opened its 'Dragon plant' in Shanghai, with an investment of more than â‚¬50m and around 600 employees. 
Henkel opened its first production facility in China in 1990, just two years after entering the market. Since then, it has been serving its customers in the entire Asia-Pacific, and other regions. 
But, a slowdown in the US manufacturing and Chinese packaging and automotive industry in the last couple of years has adversely affected the adhesive business of Henkel. Follow Us:
